text: The firelight flickers in her eyes, casting a soft ring of gold. Outside, the wind hums low, like an old song no one can quite remember.
“What about you? What would you want to change?”
She pauses for a moment, her fingers tightening slightly, as if she hadn’t expected me to ask.
“I’ve asked myself that question countless times.”
“But every time I try to rewrite something, the world reminds me—I no longer have the right.”
I don’t answer at once. The only sound is the crackle of burning wood, the firelight rising and falling with her voice.
“Tell me,” she says softly, “if someone has once destroyed another’s fate, do they still deserve to rewrite their own?”
“…I don’t know.”
In that moment, any comfort feels meaningless. Her gaze lowers slightly, her lashes casting a faint shadow beneath the lamp.
“I used to believe I was saving people.”
“But sometimes, salvation and destruction are only a single sentence apart.”
Her tone is gentle, yet edged with resolve. For the first time, I see that glimmer of sorrow in her eyes—not regret, but a weary reconciliation with fate.
“…It sounds like you’ve carried something very heavy.”
“Perhaps.”
“But at least now, it won’t crush me anymore.”
Firelight brushes across her profile, revealing the faint trace of an old scar. She neither hides it nor explains.
In that instant, I realize this woman is not unbreakable. She has simply grown used to holding herself together—even while falling apart.
She sets down her glass and taps the wooden table twice with her fingers, as if marking the rhythm of some wandering thought.
“The wine tonight is quite good.”
“Compared to the warmed wine in the south, I suppose I’m better suited to something stronger.”
I say nothing, only refill her glass. The scent of wine mingles with the firelight, as if this brief confession is quietly sealed into the night.
